item.title: Star vs. Snowflake
item.description:
This is the final installment of our schema series. We’ve seen the Star Express and the Snowflake District. Now, it’s time for the ultimate showdown. How does Conductor Mickey decide which tracks to lay down for the “Invisible City”?

In the previous posts, we explored two very different ways to organize a subway station:

  • The Star: Fast, flat, and simple.
  • The Snowflake: Detailed, organized, and space-saving.

But in the real world of Data Engineering, you can’t always have both. You have to choose your priority: Speed or Storage?

item.title: The Snowflake Schema: The 'Detailed' District
item.description:
In our Invisible City, as the population grows and the subway map expands, Conductor Mickey sometimes finds that a simple Star Hub isn’t enough. When the “Station” information becomes a giant, messy pile of repeating words, it’s time to move to the Snowflake Schema.

If the Star Schema is the “Express Line,” the Snowflake is the “Highly Detailed District.”

What is a Snowflake Schema?

In the previous post, we saw how the Star Schema keeps things simple. But what happens when your data starts repeating itself? What if you have 10 million rows, and you’ve written “United States” and “North America” 10 million times?
